name: Carathéodory conjecture
rephrased: A sufficiently smooth, closed, and convex surface in three-dimensional space must have at least two points where the principal curvatures are equal (umbilic points).
implication_form: If a surface is closed, convex, and sufficiently smooth, then it must have at least two umbilic points.
explained: The Carathéodory conjecture states that any smooth, closed, and convex surface embedded in three-dimensional Euclidean space must have at least two points known as umbilic points. An umbilic point is a location on the surface where the two principal curvatures are equal, meaning the surface curves equally in all directions at that point.
related_conjectures: Problem of umbilic points on surfaces of revolution
